[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Directory Management System (DMS) defines requirements for managing directories, transactions, and structured storage using PostgreSQL and file system operations.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: DMS supports directory structuring, access control, logging, and administrative control.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: DMS integrates with PostgreSQL for metadata storage and file systems for directory management.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: DMS provides web dashboards using React and command-line tools for administrators.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: DMS supports local storage, network directories, and authentication via system credentials.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: DMS uses REST APIs for directory operations and WebSockets for live updates.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: DMS secures data transmission using HTTPS TLS 1.3 and SMB v3 encryption.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: DMS optimizes storage for metadata and access logs.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: DMS maintains 24/7 uptime with automated backups and snapshots.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: DMS supports Linux and Windows-based storage.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: DMS links with monitoring tools for logging and reporting.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: DMS manages directories, enforces access controls, and tracks modifications.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: DMS is designed for administrators managing structured storage.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: DMS requires a stable local network for remote directory access.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: DMS depends on PostgreSQL, structured file systems, and authentication mechanisms.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Directory: A structured system for managing files and permissions.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with PostgreSQL for storing directory metadata (REQ-DB-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall interact with Linux and Windows file system APIs for directory operations (REQ-FUNC-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: Users shall create, modify, and delete directories with access control settings (REQ-DB-001, REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall log TO-BE-DEFINED (REQ-DB-001, REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide a React-based dashboard for managing directories and permissions (REQ-FUNC-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process directory modifications and permission changes within 2 seconds (REQ-FUNC-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store directory metadata, access logs, and user roles (REQ-FUNC-001, REQ-FUNC-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall enforce role-based access control with ACLs (REQ-DB-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with ISO 27001 security guidelines for access management (REQ-DB-001, REQ-DB-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall log and encrypt directory modifications and user access attempts (REQ-DB-001).

[SEC] 3. Verification: Validation covers directory creation, access control enforcement, and transaction logging accuracy.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User guides, API documentation, and system administration policies.
[SEC] 5. References: ISO 27001 Security Compliance, Linux File System Permissions, and Windows NTFS ACL Guidelines.
